segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: Welcome to the open source stories, digital archive, or FOSSDA. Open source has changed the world. And it's changed the world greatly for the better. It's a movement that's been going on for quite a while now, and it didn't start because of a government, or a company, or a politician.

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: It started really from people who wanted to change the way people had access to software because software is so important to our lives now. Whether you know it or not, you are using open-source software right now, and you're probably using it every moment of your life. And that's due to a very dedicated group of people who started, and who grew this movement over many years.

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: Because this is such an important change in our world, and because it happened in the way it did. I thought it was important to capture the personal stories of people involved in this movement. What made them so dedicated? What made them understand that this was so important?

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: And so I've asked lots of my friends, and colleagues, and people I don't even know to contribute their stories to this oral history, so that the generations who go

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: beyond and take open source forward into the 21st

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: century will understand, how such a movement could have come about.

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: Now, it's only fair that I tell my own story and it's certainly not the most interesting story you're going to hear, but I was a computer programmer a long time ago back in the 1980s.

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: It was so long ago, we called ourselves computer programmers instead of software engineers. I wrote code in compiled Basic.

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: Now, for people who are in the tech industry, that is, you know, a very lightweight way of doing computer programming, but hey, you can't judge, because it actually worked really well for what we were doing at the time. But I was very interested in software as a result. And by the way, I got into software just by kind of talking my way into a job. It's not like you went to school to get a job in that back in those days. And eventually, when I went to law

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: school and then I graduated, I found that there was all this really interesting stuff going on in software licensing.

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: My clients started to ask me, "What about these open source licenses?"

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: And they were really something new. They were not like anything anyone had seen before. And for the most part, they weren't really written entirely by lawyers or much like normal software licenses. Most of the people I worked with at the time had the attitude of, well, you know, you can't use this stuff. We don't understand it. You don't know where it's been. It's kind of like when your mother says, "Don't put that in your mouth. You don't know where it's been." And but my clients kept asking me about it, and I thought that instead of the answer just being, "No", which was the answer most lawyers were giving it the time,

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: I had to say, "Yes, if..."

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: And so I started trying to figure out how to do that and there wasn't much out there. Not a lot of information out there. And so I actually started creating some of the information. And I found it was just an absolutely fascinating thing.

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: I mean, people get into the law for different reasons, but I think actually for a lot of lawyers, they get into it because being a lawyer is like solving all these really intricate puzzles. And by the way, that's very similar to what programming is like and I love both of those things.

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: So I started trying to unpack this puzzle and figure it out. And it's been so interesting and sustained me for decades now in my practice, and it's made my practice better than I could have ever expected. Just the pure interest value of, it is really what gets me out of bed and at my desk every morning,

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: So I have had a wonderful time focusing on open source software licensing over the years.

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: Well, I hope you enjoy listening to the stories in this archive,

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: and I hope it helps make you think about how people can change the world.

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: Thanks so much for listening.

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: Okay, I think we're going. All right. Hello. I am very happy today to be talking to Bruce Perens, who is one of the founders of the Open Source movement and who created the 'open source' definition. You know, it's impossible to catalog all of Bruce's achievements in a short introduction and to most in the open source world, he doesn't need any introduction.

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: But I'll mention a couple of things. He's the creator of BusyBox, which is a key software utility for Linux system that everybody uses all the time, and he was a key developer at Pixar, helping to create the technology of 3D animated feature films. Bruce, welcome to FOSSDA!

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: Well, thank you very much, Heather.

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: So glad that you're willing to take the time to talk to me today. So, I'd like to know what got you involved in open source? How'd you decide to get involved in/create this movement of open source?

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: Well, obviously, I'm standing on the shoulders of giants because the work of Richard Stallman preceeded mine, and the basic concepts of open source are those created by Richard for free software. What we did with open source was create a marketing program for the free software concept which would reach different people. So, Richard's approach was very well suited for programmers, but it depended on the apriori understanding of the usefulness of software freedom.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And our approach was more based on just having a big collection of software that you could build, whether it was a business or any project that you wanted to, you could build these upon, you could share the development of the software and my feeling personally was that the philosophy would come later for a lot of the people who participated.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And so, obviously, we were successful beyond our wildest dreams. We took over, essentially, the software industry. Open source is everywhere. Whether you understand it or not, you encounter it in your life all day. And so, that has been very fulfilling.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: We did not achieve all of our goals. Actually, I would have liked it if people did appreciate the need for software freedom, which is something that is becoming more meaningful today, especially in the context of privacy and people seeing the large web companies, as sort of privacy eating giants, don't really have your best interest in mind.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And open source, though very successful, I think, has evolved a extremely capable open source, exploitation industry. So, I'm not quite so happy about that, I actually am working on solutions.

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: Well, so, tell me at the very beginning - and by the way, I kind of know some of the answer to this because you and I have known each other for a long time but -

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: Yeah but we have an audience so let's conquer that!

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: Yeah, right! How did you actually get involved in the development of open source? What was the motivation for doing that in the first place?

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: Well, I had been a Unix systems programmer since 1981 and that was at the lab that was the predecessor of Pixar. It was at New York Tech, a otherwise not-very-memorable college, that had the computer graphics laboratory - almost a hobby of the chancellor of this college, the late Alexander Schure - and we were creating 3D feature character animation in that laboratory.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: A lot of the people went on to Pixar, also many other places - Disney, Dreamworks, all over. And so, I was into Unix and eventually went to work for Pixar. And one day, I actually sat across from Steve Jobs' office, not because I was important, I think they wanted to keep an eye on me.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And so, one day, Steve made his peace with Bill Gates and where there had been a NeXT workstation on Steve's desk, there was now a Windows laptop and for a time at Pixar, Steve felt that computing would just all turn to Microsoft Windows and I have asserted down on that. I didn't actually think of it as a very capable system, especially at the time because Microsoft didn't have competition that would give it a strong quality incentive like they have now.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And so, Linux started to come along because of a number of factors. The Canoe project had developed all of what we call runtime. So all of the programs that would run on it, and the libraries for the most part were a product of the Canoe project - but the Canoe project was not successful in developing a kernel, which is the part that connects the hardware and the software - and so, Linus Torvalds came along and made a successful kernel.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: At the start it didn't have networking, you know, people don't remember the Linux didn't actually work on the net successfully for quite a while and people started to create Linux distributions and there were a number of for-profit ones, most of which no one has ever heard of today. And Ian Murdock saw this happening and said, well, let's create a non-profit one and he created Debian which most people actually know through Ubuntu today and I joined, I guess, there must have been 50 people on the whole project at the time, and eventually became the Debian project leader.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: Ian went on to other things and took the project and did something that no one knew was possible at that time, which was that Ian had made all of the core of the project, everything that it needed to boot and run and install packages, had been produced by Ian.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And I took it and obviously didn't have the time to work on all of these packages and fanned them out to 50 people who I only knew from email correspondence on the net. I was a Debian project leader, I had never actually met another Debian developer, and fanned it out. And these 50 people who also did not physically know each other combined to create a working, running, operating system. And obviously, the software was very modular and that certainly helped us get away with that but also the fact that open source let us all sort of look over each other's shoulders and help each other was very useful as well.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: So all of these people who had no common employer, who hadn't met at that time, and who really only had their own private goals driving this - I think, at that point, none of them were actually doing this for their employer - combined to create a working operating system that among other things, flew on the space shuttle controlling an experiment, was very, very successful.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And most of the work that we did at that time survives in the Linux system that you are using today, some of it in your Android telephones. Because I wrote BusyBox, BusyBox was the installer. The whole idea of BusyBox is it's all of the commands that you might need to install an operating system on a computer made smaller so that they all would fit on a floppy disk.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: Okay, that's how far back this goes. We had those three-and-a-half inch plastic floppy disks and the kernel fit on one and all of the runtime and BusyBox fit on the second one. And so, you would boot your system using these two floppy disks and then you would be able to put a CD in the CD drive and install the entire distribution from it.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: I don't think we even had bootable CD at that point. And if you didn't have a CD, we also had a way to make rather large collection of floppy disks, and you would also just keep feeding floppies into your computer until you had a system installed. You know, going back this far, I think I had 240 megabyte hard drives on the computer I was using for development. So, thats actually practical to feed this all with that amount of floppies, and this worked!

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And I, actually, for all of the work that other people have done upon it and all of the legal issues, which later popped up, I worked on BusyBox for an entire month and I never touched it again. I created about 35 programs in that month and subsequent to that, it was adopted by a series of other programmers who made tremendous improvements to it, but I actually checked and my code is still in it.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And I used the GPL license, and the GPL license is a share-and-share-alike license and thus, if you made improvements to this program, you had to share the improvement. So my original investment of a month of evenings I should have been spending with my wife, really, was tremendously, tremendously expanded by the subsequent work of all of these people which they did under the GPL license contribute when in some cases the incentive for them would have been to keep their modifications private.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: So we had two embedded systems- companies that decided to make embedded Linux and deal it to a number of commercial companies that were putting it on various kinds of hardware. And one of them was Linio and I don't even remember the name of the other now.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And those companies achieved a six months time to market lead by using my software rather than creating their own and this was in terms of- it might have taken some of their guys that long to add all of the software and make it all work. And so they built on my software and the software became much much larger, got up above a hundred and thirty commands.

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: So bigger than a floppy disk?

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: Yeah and essentially a small but capable command line system that you could do many different things with. And so, that system became part of a lot of Android telephones, of part of wireless access points, if you use- well, the open source project OpenWrt uses it.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: Then many commercial, wireless access point designs are derived from that. For example, there are very many embedded devices for the most mundane uses - aquarium temperature controllers that all have this software in them, and webcams, all kinds of things.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And so, for something that I spent a month upon, I did not ever receive financial compensation directly from it, but it has tens and hundreds of millions of users. All right. Users who don't necessarily even know that it exists but there is some pride in that, just as an artist likes to have their paintings appreciated, a programmer likes to have lots of users and lots of things happening with their software.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And today, I know that a jet plane does not fly without using BusyBox and you don't, you probably don't wake up and get into your day without using BusyBox. And so, that's really fun and it was worth that months of evenings and Valerie and I are still together even though I probably neglected her for that whole month.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And so, we didn't receive direct payment for this, but I did receive a great deal of notoriety which has led to a lot of other opportunities. One of the most fun was I was in a commercial for IBM Linux after they bought Red Hat. I think this was actually a mistake that the casting person cast me and then I think there was quite a to-do within IBM because they would have vastly preferred to cast someone from Red Hat, but I ended up being the face of Linux for IBM for a good eight months and actually IBM's conference that year.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: They opened with an extended video from the commercial. So, the conference opens and the very first thing that people see is my face and I got fifty thousand dollars for a couple hours work. You know, Hollywood is that way when you're successful and I'm sure it's very, very difficult when you're not.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And so that was one of the things but I've had most of my employment and consulting opportunities are connected to this work that I did - oh gee, now it's coming up on 30 years ago - and so that's just been great fun. Obviously, I have some regrets over the way that things have come out, but it's been incredibly more successful than anyone could have ever asked so those things are very tempered. So, that's probably enough for one question.

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: Well, that's really great. Thank you. I mean, you were doing this all during the time you were still working at Pixar, isn't that right?

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: Yeah, I was working at Pixar and, as I said, I worked for Steve Jobs. Not directly, I had managers. There was Ed Catmull, the CEO, who now, I guess, is a CEO of Disney, if he's still there. And I was a Systems Programmer for Imaging for the most part so I invented image composing language and did a great deal of work for them.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: But one of the things I noticed was that, for the most part, my work for Pixar, all end of life while I was still working there, was replaced with something else. And of course, when you make software for a movie, we go on to the next movie and we don't always use the same software.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And, so, during this time, Pixar made their IPO, which was very useful because I had enough money from the IPO to pay off my mortgage and I could be a flake because unlike everybody else in Silicon Valley, I didn't have this incredible mortgage that I would take many, many years to pay off. And so, I could work full-time on open source and, you know, see where the money came in, which it usually did.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And so, I remember at the time someone saying to me "well, Pixar is having its IPO and you have Toy Story coming out, and isn't this wonderful?" And at the time, the space shuttle had just launched with Debian Linux and the biosciences project on it and I said well, you know, it's cool to have a movie in theaters and to have an IPO that's being very successful but my hobby project is orbiting in space and that's actually more fulfilling to me.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And I remember actually finding out that this would happen. The way it happened was, someone wrote to me, someone who I did not know, and I was at my desk at Pixar and and said, can I boot Debian on a serial console? And I had never done this because I had only developed on desktops that had VGA cards at the time, you know, lower resolution graphical displays.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And I said, well, that's interesting and I have on my desk here at Pixar, would I need to test that? So, I took 15 minutes from Pixar, and I tested it and took another 15 minutes and documented my changes back to back out so I could get back to my work at Pixar and wrote back to the Sky Sebastian Kuznetsky and said here's what you need to do. And he wrote back and said that works great, this is going on the next space shuttle.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And so, you know, imagine me at my desk at Pixar with my jaw now unhinged and on the floor somewhere and I got up and I walked all around the building looking for someone to tell this to. And the only person who understood about Linux was Loren Carpenter, a very famous computer graphic person, and Loren was working from home that day so that there was no one at Pixar I could tell this to who would have a clue of what was happening and not think I was crazy.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And that kind of decided me that Pixar wasn't really my future. And there had been other things they had actually restarted vesting from zero and I'd been there for eight years, which was kind of annoying. And so I, at that point, you know, said to myself, I'm going to have to work for this company 12 years to be vested in my stock.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And Pixar had actually gone bankrupt once or twice on the way to success and Steve had funded them out of pocket. His advisor, his financial advisor, told him, you know, you probably shouldn't do this again, but he gave us another chance. And so, essentially, the day after I was fully vested after 12 years at Pixar, I left and went to work for my first venture capital operation was called Linux Capital group and it was not successful; I'm in another unsuccessful one today.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And so, I worked for them for a while and that did not work out and then I left that company essentially so that they would not have to pay me and they'd be able to keep Progeny Linux systems, which was Ian's company, afloat. That worked for 7 years, but they eventually closed that one, too.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And so, I went to work for Hewlett-Packard as Senior Global Strategist of Linux and Open Source and that was all because of the notoriety that I had accumulated as, you know, an open source spokesperson and developer.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: So, I remember leaving Pixar and walked into Steve's office and, you know, there were a lot of stories about Steve. Steve was never nasty to me and probably because I got there first. I was a pretty obnoxious guy, you know, still am in many ways, and I was very aggressive. And so I think that Steve and I were sort of on the same wavelength in that regard.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And so I walked in and he knew I was leaving and I said "You still don't believe in this Linux stuff" and Steve, you know, Mr. Ego, said to me "Well, I've been involved in creating two of the three great operating systems" - and by that, he meant, Mac OS and NeXTSTEP - "and all of them took a billion-dollar laboratory and I don't think that you can get over the hump because you don't have the billion-dollar laboratory".

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And so, you know, shook Steve's hand, said goodbye. Never actually communicated with Steve, again. I sent him one or two emails and never got a reply. He wasn't one to talk to ex-employees.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And a year later though, Steve got on stage at Macworld and introduced the Safari browser. And the Safari browser was graphical web browser based on the KDE Open Source Graphics Project. So the point there was that graphics developed by open source had already exceeded what they could do inside Apple. And that Apple was leveraging upon it in order to get a leg up on the web browser development, which they were kind of behind on at that point, and if you ask me, they're still behind today.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And so, Steve stood on the stage at Macworld in front of a huge slide saying "Open Source, We Love It" and although Steve never acknowledged it, I won that argument.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: Come on, Heather!

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: Well, that's one of those things like 'revenge is a dish best served cold', something like that. Not exactly revenge, but everybody, I guess, comes around to open source eventually. It's just a matter of how long it takes them to do that, right?

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: Ah. Yeah, I mean, back then was when Craig Mundie had said Linux is a virus, it will steal your intellectual property. And today, obviously, Microsoft is part of the open-source exploitation industry.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: They're not just using it for their health but they are participants in open source to a degree that no one at Microsoft or outside would have believed when this all started. And that's what really gets me is, so many things have happened that no one would have believed. And mostly because the economics, though real, was not intuitive.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And so, if I had said to you, I'm going to get together with my friends who I've never met on the internet and develop an encyclopedia and it's going to put Encyclopedia Britannica out of business so far that they don't even make the printed version anymore, you would have said "You're on drugs, Bruce". And, you know, if I'd said I'm going to make an operating system that essentially takes over the industry, they would have said the same thing and all of these happened.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And without boring people to tears, there's a paper I wrote about this called "The Emerging Economic Paradigm of Open Source" and it's 15 years old and still current, and if you want to understand the economics, read that.

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: Yeah, it's really- it's been an amazing journey for everybody. I think that maybe for you, more than most people. You know, I'd like to ask a little bit more about like, what what was it like collaborating with 50 people you didn't know? I mean, you said that was considered impossible at the time. Now, I think, people probably almost take it as a given?

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: I'd like to know your thoughts about how how that came about, why it worked, some cases where it didn't work - whatever you'd like to talk about about sort of the community aspect of it.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: Um, I think that the software collaboration was very successful. A lot of the organizational efforts were not. For example, during this time, I drove the creation of software in the public interest, non-profit that's still very active in supporting open source projects, and there was vast distrust among the Debian developers of software in the public interest.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And I think that it would have been legally advantageous for the developers to be working on behalf of this non-profit which would actually take up the liability because they were individuals, and if they got sued, they were out of the game. And software in the public interest would probably have been able if it were sued to get help from kind people like you.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And so, this was vastly distrusted by the developers and, you know, it was a non-profit. I wasn't about to take the money and pocket it or even pay myself. So the reasons for it really escape me. So there were failures like that, but in general, if you were just making software, everybody was willing to give a hand in making software and at that time, I think email communication felt natural to us.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And there's actually an interesting but somewhat creepy aspect of it, which is, we don't really like to admit that a great many of us programmers are on the spectrum, and are very capable and had very successful lives, but may have been a little debilitated with regard to personal interaction.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And many of these people are actually more comfortable collaborating with the community entirely textually, not looking at their faces, not having to parse their voice tone. And to some degree, that may have actually helped us and it's actually sad that for the most part those people cannot collaborate in that way any longer that the technology is improved to the point that you and I are looking at each other's faces again, where we at the time, would not have heard each other's voice and would not have seen each other.

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: Yeah, I think that's very interesting that there's a kind of temporal disconnect and personal disconnect that's possible in these asynchronous, like, development platforms and so forth that work very well for some people.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: Yeah, and also, if you're one of these programmers who has some social issues, computing is a very comfortable environment for you because your computer doesn't dislike you and not work with you because it doesn't like your face. Your program runs if it's correct, and it doesn't run until it's correct. And so these were the, that was also something that was very comfortable for the kind of person who really does like to stay in their cube and code, and, you know, do their work with the world that way.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: Now, I sort of bridged both of those worlds. I think people know this by now, I am not neurotypical. And so I have some of those issues, but I'm also very, very well trained.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: While I think it might have been better at the time to put me in speech therapy, my schools didn't have that. So they just put me in rhetoric class every year. And so, I had, you know, practically an hour of public speech practice every day, for perhaps a decade of my life, and came out of this a really good public speaker and was able to evangelize this stuff where other people might not have.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And, in fact, I actually have the opposite of the fear of public speaking. I have a fear of being in audiences because I will feel so strongly about a subject that I'll be tempted to argue with the speaker, and actually have. So I'm actually more comfortable if I'm up there talking and that probably doesn't say good things about me.

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: Well, you certainly have been a beloved advocate for all these years and I think it's very interesting that some of that came out of dealing with a challenge, you know, but you you were able to turn it to something that benefitted everyone.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: An actual, actual physical handicap. I cound not talk clearly, I could not move the way other people moved. And, you know, these things, you can, sometimes, age out of them, but it was a great part of what made me, what I am.

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: Well, that's really great. So anything else you'd like to share before we wrap up? This has been a fascinating conversation and even though I've known you for a long time, always really like hearing about your story over again, or, you know, or different aspects of it. Anything else you'd like to share before we stop?

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: Well, I think that this is a kind of success that other people don't always achieve and I would encourage everyone to follow their dreams, work on what you love to the extent that you can. I mean, don't make your family broke. But sometimes, you can achieve these things and internet collaboration has made so much more of this possible.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: And that was something that I really touched upon it. That time, no one understood all of the implications that there were projects, that at the time, people just would have been considered nuts for working on. But when you have 50 nuts who believe the same as you on the internet, you're more powerful than any startup company. And so, today you can achieve incredible things and I would encourage everyone to give that a try. See if they can do it.

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
segments.text: That's great. Well, thanks so much, Bruce. I really appreciate your talking to me today and contributing this to FOSSDA.

segments.speaker: Bruce Perens
segments.text: Thanks very much, Heather.

segments.speaker: Heather Meeker
